
[TITLE]
<line: 2> UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
<line: 3> DISTRICT OF NEW JERSEY

[TITLE]
<line: 5> JESUS RODRIGUEZ

[TEXT]
<line: 7> Civ. No. 16-1315 (KM)

[TEXT]
<line: 9> Petitioner,

[TEXT]
<line: 11> I.

[TEXT]
<line: 13> OPINION

[TEXT]
<line: 15> STEVEN JOHNSON and THE ATTORNEY
<line: 16> GENERAL OF THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY.

[TEXT]
<line: 18> Respondents.

[TITLE]
<line: 20> KEVIN MCNULTY, U.S.D.J.

[TITLE]
<line: 22> I.
<line: 23> INTRODUCTION

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Before this Court is the petition for a writ of habeas corpus pursuant to 28 U.S.C. $ 2254.
<line: 26> filed by petitioner Jesus Rodriguez ("Mr. Rodriguez" or "Petitioner). (DE 1.) Mr. Rodriguez is
<line: 27> presently confined at New Jersey State Prison in Trenton. New Jersey. For the reasons set forth
<line: 28> below. Mr. Rodriguez's habeas petition and renewed motion for an evidentiary hearing are.
<line: 29> denied, and a certificate of appealability will not issue.

[TITLE]
<line: 31> H.
<line: 32> BACKGROUND

[TEXT]
<line: 34> A. Factual Background

[TEXT]
<line: 36> This Court, affording the state courts' factual determinations the appropriate deference..
<line: 37> see 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(e)(1).' will reproduce the pertinent relevant facts set forth by the Appellate
<line: 38> Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey (*Appellate Division") in (1) its April 12, 2004

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> Pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  2254(e)(1), "[i]n a proceeding instituted by an application for a writ of.
<line: 41> habeas corpus by a person in custody pursuant to the judgment of a State court, a determination of a
<line: 42> factuat issue made by a State court shall be presumed to be correct. The applicant shall have the burden
<line: 43> of rebutting the presumption of correctness by clear and convincing evidence."

[TEXT]
<line: 2> written opinion during direct appeal (State v. Romero, Nos. A-4974-99. A-6593-99. A-0282-
<line: 3> 00, A-0834-00, A-5704-00 (App. Div. Apr. 12, 2004) (slip op. at 1-118) (DE 10-2; DE 10-3)):
<line: 4> and (2) its August 26, 2015 written opinion afirming denial of post-conviction relief (PCR")
<line: 5> (State r. Rodrigues, No. A-3656-12T1. 2015 WL 5038103, at *1 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. Aug.
<line: 6> 26. 2015).)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> Mr. Rodriguez and nine co-defendants were members of a local New Jersey chapter of a
<line: 9> national organization called the Latin Kings. The Orange Crush was an elite enforcement group
<line: 10> of the Latin Kings, appointed by defendant Luis Manso. a Latin Kings regional officer. Orange
<line: 11> Crush handled special problems of Latin Kings members. Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *1.
<line: 12> (DE 10-2 at 9.)

[TEXT]
<line: 14> According to defendant David Martinez. defendant Michael Romero held a Latin Kings
<line: 15> member meeting at his Jersey City home on June 29. 1998. He explained that. the day before.
<line: 16> Omar D. Morante (Omar D") and Jimmy Cabrera had conducted a drive-by shooting at his
<line: 17> apartment complex. Mr. Romero believed that he had been the shooting's intended target. He
<line: 18> wanted the Latin Kings to retaliate on his behalf. Defendant Charles Byrd. who attended the
<line: 19> meeting. agreed. He ordered Orange Crush to kidnap Omar D and Jimmy Cabrera that night
<line: 20> break their shooting arms, and then kill them. Rodriguez. 2015 WL 5038103, at *1.

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Later that day, roughly twenty-live Latin Kings members met at Romero's hone. Id. al
<line: 23> *2. After that meeting. David Martinez drove Edwin Rivera's Bronco, with Edwin Rivera.
<line: 24> Miguel Torres, Juan Cortes, and Omar W. Morante (Omar W")as passengers. Luis Manso
<line: 25> drove his car, with Michael Romero, Jose Antonio Perez, and Omar D (Omar W's twin brother))
<line: 26> as passengers. Juan DeJesus drove Jesus Rodriguez's vehicle, with Jesus Rodriguez. Luis

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Rodriguez, Edwin Diaz, Jimmy Cabrera, and Sfand Rajabzaden as passengers. Id. (DE 10-2 at 8-
<line: 3> 9.)

[TEXT]
<line: 5> Because David Martinez was not sure of their destination in Newark, he pulled over near.
<line: 6> an interchange on the New Jersey Turnpike. The other cars followed. Luis Manso used the pay
<line: 7> phones at the interchange to call Charles Byrd and confirm that their orders were to carry out the
<line: 8> punishment without a *trial." According to David Martinez, while Luis Manso was speaking to
<line: 9> Charles Byrd, Jesus Rodriguez asked to speak to Charles Byrd to persuade him that a *trial" was
<line: 10> necessary, but Luis Manso told him that Charles Byrd refused to reconsider the issue. According
<line: 11> to Juan DeJesus, when Luis Manso hung up the phone, he said: *[Byrd] said we got to do this."
<line: 12> Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *1.

[TEXT]
<line: 14> While they were stopped at the Turnpike rest area, Omar W -- fearing the others
<line: 15> intended plan -- sought the help of a toll collector. under the guise of using the restroom. The
<line: 16> collector directed him to a nearby toll oflice. Recognizing what was transpiring. Luis Martinez
<line: 17> tried to interrupt by grabbing Omar W's arm. When the toll collector objected. Martinez released
<line: 18> Omar W, and the cars pulled away. Intended victims Omar W and Juan Cortes escaped from the
<line: 19> cars. (DE 10-2 at 9.)

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Intended victims Omar D and Jimmy Cabrera. however, were taken to Branch Brook.
<line: 22> Park in Newark, where they were strangled to death and left lying face down in the water. (DE
<line: 23> 10-2 a1 9.)

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Two eyewitnesses to the murders. Ricardo Diaz and Luis Rodriguez. testified for the.
<line: 26> State. Although their versions of the circumstances surrounding the murders differed to some
<line: 27> extent, each testified that Jesus Rodriguez and Michael Romero direct!y participated in the

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 3

[TEXT]
<line: 2> killings. Rodrigues. 2015 WL 5038103. at *2. The two witnesses also testified that Luis Manso
<line: 3> was at the scene and said *Set it off." after which the attack began. Id..

[TEXT]
<line: 5> According to Ricardo Diaz, Jesus Rodriguez grabbed Omar D in a headlock in the park..
<line: 6> then handed him over to Juan Antonio Perez. (DE 10-2 at 16.) Michael Romero grabbed Jimmy
<line: 7> Cabrera, who was not fighting back much. (Id.) However, Omar D was resisting so strongly that
<line: 8> Michae! Romero had to help Juan Antonio Perez. who held down Omar D while Michael
<line: 9> Romero beat him with a belt. (Id.) Romero also kicked and punched Cabrera, tore off his shirt.
<line: 10> twisted it around his neck, and instructed Diaz to hold it tightly -- which he did until Cabrera
<line: 11> stopped moving. Id. Ricardo Diaz further testified that Luis Manso directed him to drag.
<line: 12> Cabrera's body to the water, which he did. Rodriguez, 2015 WL 5038103, at *2..

[TEXT]
<line: 14> According to State witness Luis Rodriguez. Luis Manso ordered him to help Juan
<line: 15> Antonio Perez drown Omar D. but Luis Rodriguez refused. Rodrigues. 2015 WL 5038103. at *1.
<line: 16> Omar D was still struggling. so they dragged him towards the water as he screamed: "I'll tell you
<line: 17> whatever you want, just don't kill me. Leave me alone please." Michae! Romero and Juan.
<line: 18> Antonio Perez appeared to be trying to drown Omar D. and when he stopped moving. Perez.
<line: 19> dragged the body further into the water. At Luis Mlanso's direction. Ricardo Diaz dragged Jinmy
<line: 20> Cabrera's body to the water. as well. (DE 10-2 at 16.).

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Ricardo Diaz left the crime scene in Jesus Rodriguez's car with Jesus Rodriguez, Luis.
<line: 23> Rodriguez. and Juan DeJesus. (Id.) Luis Rodriguez asked Diaz "if that was his first. and he was
<line: 24> speechless." (Id.) Luis Rodriguez said, -That kid put up a fight," and Jesus Rodriguez said..
<line: 25> *Yeah, [he] was strong." (Id. at 16-17.).

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Juan DeJesus also lestified for the State. He explained that he stayed in the car at the.
<line: 28> scene of the attack because Jesus Rodriguez had told him to do so. Juan DeJesus did not witness

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> the murders. He testified, however, that he saw the others run sweaty and dirty from the bushes.
<line: 3> Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *2.

[TITLE]
<line: 5> B. Procedural History

[TEXT]
<line: 7> In November 1998, Mr. Rodriguez and his nine co-defendants were indicted and charged
<line: 8> in eighteen counts with six different crimes against four victims, two of whom were killed. They
<line: 9> were all charged with four counts of second-degree conspiracy to commit kidnapping: four
<line: 10> counts of first-degree kidnapping; four counts of second-degree conspiracy to commit murder;
<line: 11> two counts of murder; two counts of felony murder; and two counts of attempted murder. Edwin
<line: 12> Diaz, who was also charged with additional counts, Ricardo Diaz, David Martinez, Sfand
<line: 13> Rajabzaden, Edwin Rivera, and Miguel Torres pled guilty. The trial judge denied motions for
<line: 14> separate trials. Id. at * I.

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Mr. Rodriguez and co-defendants Luis Manso, Michael Romero. Jose Antonio Perez, and!
<line: 17> Charles Byrd were tried jointly between January 24 and March 17. 2000. Idl. Mr. Rodriguez was
<line: 18> sentenced on April 26, 2000 and received two consecutive life sentences for the murder
<line: 19> convictions, eighty-five percent without parole; four concurrent life sentences for the kidnapping.
<line: 20> convictions, eighty-five percent without parole; and concurrent fifty-year sentences for the
<line: 21> attempted murder convictions. The remaining convictions merged. (DE 10-2 at 7.) Mr.
<line: 22> Rodriguez and the co-defendants who were tried with him appealed. In an unpublished opinion,
<line: 23> the Appellate Division affirmed the convictions.State r. Romero, Nos. A-4974 99, A--6593-99.
<line: 24> A-0282-00, A-0834-00. A-5704-00 (App. Div. Apr. 12, 2004) (slip op. at 1-118) (DE 10-2:
<line: 25> DE 10-3.) The Supreme Court denied certification. State r. Romero, 181 N.J. 548 (2004).

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Mr. Rodriguez filed his PCR petition in March 2005. He raised issues primarily related to
<line: 3> allegations of constitutionally ineffective assistance of trial, appellate. and PCR counsel. as well
<line: 4> as trial errors not raised on direct appeal. See Rodriguez, 2015 wL 5038103. at *2..

[TEXT]
<line: 6> The PCR judge held an evidentiary hearing on Mr. Rodriguez's PCR petition, as well as
<line: 7> those filed by Mr. Manso, Mr. Romero, and Mr. Perez. Rodriguez, 2015 WL 5038103, at *3. In a
<line: 8> written decision and order dated January 7, 2013, the PCR judge denied relief and dismissed Mr.
<line: 9> Rodriguez's petition. (DE 10-6.) He reached the same result with respect to the petitions filed by
<line: 10> the other three defendants. (Id.) Rodriguez, 2015 WL 5038103, at *3..

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Mr. Rodriguez appealed the denial of PCR, raising seven issues, including his trial
<line: 13> attorney's IAC for "fail[ure] to attend or procure replacement counsel for all jury selection.
<line: 14> proceedings." (DE 10-5 at 3.) In his pro se supplemental brief. Mr. Rodriguez argued that trial
<line: 15> counse! rendered lAC by "fail[ing] to advise [Petitioner] on whether or not to testify, to inform
<line: 16> him that the choice whether to testify was ultimately his to make, and to honor [Petitioner's]
<line: 17> wish to testify." (DE 10-6 at 3.) In a second pro se supplemental brief. Mr. Rodriguez again
<line: 18> argued IAC by trial counsel's failure to inform him of his right to testify, which prejudiced him.
<line: 19> (DE 10-7 at 5.) Rodriguez.2015 WL 5038103. at *3.

[TEXT]
<line: 21> In a detailed written opinion filed on August 26. 2015, the Appellate Division aflirmed
<line: 22> denial of PCR. Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *5-10.

[TEXT]
<line: 24> On March 3, 2016, Mr. Rodriguez filed his $ 2254 Petition with this Court. (DE 1 at 17.)

[TEXT]
<line: 26> He raises four grounds-for relief: (1) ineffective assistance of counsel ("IAC) by his trial.

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 2
<line: 29> With respect to claims of ineffective assistance of counsel (*lAC") by his trial counsel, Paul.
<line: 30> Feinberg, Esquire, Mr. Rodriguez argued that Feinberg: failed to request severance of Mr. Rodriguez's
<line: 31> case from those of his co-defendants; failed to object to the State's systematic elimination of Hispanics
<line: 32> from the jury; failed to be present at all times during jury selection; failed to adequately investigate the
<line: 33> case; failed to request a hearing on Mr. Rodriguez's minor status; and made "serious omissions and.
<line: 34> derelictions of duty."(DE 10-6 a1 77-78.).

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> attorney in failing to advise Mr. Rodriguez of his right to testify at trial (DE I at 23): (2) IAC by
<line: 3> trial counsel in failing to be present for three days during jury selection (id. at 25): (3) violation
<line: 4> of Mr. Rodriguez's due process rights when *a juror who had been intimidated by outsiders was
<line: 5> allowed to remain on the jury" (id. at 26); and (4) unconstitutional exclusion of Hispanics from
<line: 6> the venire or the jury as seated. (Id. at 27.)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> On May 2, 2016, Respondents filed an answer (DE 10), to which Mr. Rodriguez filed a
<line: 9> reply. (DE 24.)

[TITLE]
<line: 11> 11I.
<line: 12> LEGAL STANDARDS

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Under 28 U.S.C.  2254(a), the district court *shall entertain an application for a writ of
<line: 15> habeas corpus [o]n behalf of a person in custody pursuant to the judgment of a State court only
<line: 16> on the ground that he is in custody in violation of the Constitution or laws or treaties of the
<line: 17> United States." A habeas petitioner has the burden of establishing his entitlement to relief for
<line: 18> each claim presented in his petition based upon the record that was before the state court. See
<line: 19> Eley r. Erickson, 712 F.3d 837, 846 (3d Cir. 2013): see also Parker r. Mutthews, 567 U.S. 37.
<line: 20> 40-41 (2012). District courts are required to give great deference to the determinations of the
<line: 21> state trial and appellate courts. See Renico r. Lelt. 559 U.S. 766. 773 (2010).

[TEXT]
<line: 23> In general, a federal court may not grant a writ of habeas corpus under $ 2254 unless the
<line: 24> petitioner has "exhausted the remedies available in the courts of the State." 28 U.S.C. $
<line: 25> 2254(b)(l)(A). To do so, a petitioner must * fairly present' all federal clains to the highest state
<line: 26> court before bringing them in federal court." Leyva v. Iilliams, 504 F.3d 357, 365 (3d Cir. 2007)
<line: 27> (citing Stevens v. Delavare Corr. Ctr., 295 F.3d 361, 369 (3d Cir. 2002)). This requirement
<line: 28> ensures that state courts *have *an initial opportunity to pass upon and correct alleged violations
<line: 29> of prisoners' federal rights.'" Id. (citing United States v. Bendolph. 409 F.3d 155, 173 (3d Cir.

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 2005) (quoting Duckvorth . Serrano, 454 U.S. 1, 3 (1981)). Even if a petitioner's constitutional
<line: 3> claims are unexhausted, however, a habeas court has the discretion to deny them on the merits
<line: 4> under 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(b)(2). See Taylor r. Horn, 504 F.3d 416. 427 (3d Cir. 2007); Bronshtein
<line: 5> v. Horn, 404 F.3d 700, 728 (3d Cir. 2005).

[TEXT]
<line: 7> Where a claim has been adjudicated on the merits by the state courts, the district court
<line: 8> shall not grant an application for a writ of habeas corpus unless that state court adjudication

[TEXT]
<line: 10> (1) resulted in a decision that was contrary to, or involved an
<line: 11> unreasonable application of. clearly established Federal law, as.
<line: 12> determined by the Supreme Court of the United States; or

[TEXT]
<line: 14> (2) resulted in a decision that was based on an unreasonable
<line: 15> determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented in the.
<line: 16> State court proceeding.

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(d)(1)-(2). Federal law is clearly established for these purposes where it is
<line: 19> clearly expressed in **only the holdings, as opposed to the dicta" of the opinions of the United
<line: 20> States Supreme Court. See Iloods r. Donald. 135 S. Ct. 1372. 1376 (2015). "When reviewing
<line: 21> state criminal convictions on collateral review, federal judges are required to afford state courts
<line: 22> due respect by overturning their decisions only when there could be no reasonable dispute that
<line: 23> they were wrong.' Id. Where a petitioner challenges an allegedly erroneous factual determination
<line: 24> of the state courts, *"a determination of a factual issue made by a State court shall be presumed to
<line: 25> be correct [and the] applicant shall have the burden of rebutting the presumption of correctness
<line: 26> by clear and convincing evidence." 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(e)(1).

[TEXT]
<line: 28>  For any particular issue, the relevant state court decision for purposes of federal habeas
<line: 29> review is the last reasoned state court decision. See Bondd r. Beard, 539 F.3d 256, 289-90 (3d Cir
<line: 30> 2008). These deferentia! standards apply, however, *even where there has been a summary.
<line: 31> denial" by the state court. Cullen v. Pinholster, 563 U.S. 170, 187 (2011). "In these.

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> circumstances, [petitioner] can satisfy the *unreasonable application* prong of $ 2254(d)(1) only
<line: 3> by showing that 'there was no reasonable basis' for the [state court's] decision." Id. at 187-88
<line: 4> (quoting Harrington v. Richter, 562 U.S. 86, 98 (2011)). Furthermore, "when the relevant state-
<line: 5> court decision on the merits ...does not come accompanied with .. reasons... [w]e hold that the
<line: 6> federal court should -look through' the unexplained decision to the last related state-court
<line: 7> decision that does provide a relevant rationale." 1/ilson v. Sellers, 138 S. Ct. 1188. 1192 (2018).

[TEXT]
<line: 9> Because many of the claims sound in IAC, I review the governing standards briefly. In
<line: 10> Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688 (1984). the U.S. Supreme Court held that a claim of
<line: 11>  ineffective assistance of counsel claim has two essential elements.

[TEXT]
<line: 13> First, the petitioner must show that counsel's performance fell below an objective
<line: 14> standard of reasonableness. See 466 U.S. at 688; see also Ross r. Iarano, 712 F.3d 784, 798 (3d
<line: 15> Cir. 2013). To do so, the petitioner must identify particular acts or omissions that were not the
<line: 16> result of reasonable professional judgment. See Strickland, 466 U.S. at 690. The federal court
<line: 17> must determine whether, in light of all of the circumstances. the identified acts or omissions fell
<line: 18> outside the wide range of professional competent assistance. See id.

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Second, the petitioner must affirmatively demonstrate prejudice. "Prejudice" means that
<line: 21> "there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's unprofessional crrors. the result of the
<line: 22> proceeding would have been different. A reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to
<line: 23> undermine confidence in the outcome." See id. at 694; see also McBride r. Superintendent, SCI
<line: 24> Houzdale, 687 F.3d 92, 102 n. 11 (3d Cir. 2012). *With respect to the sequence of the two
<line: 25> prongs, the Strickland Court held that 'a court need not determine whether counsel's
<line: 26> performance was deficient before examining the prejudice suffered by the defendant as a result
<line: 27> of the alleged deficiencies .. If it is easier to dispose of an ineffectiveness claim on the ground of

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 2> lack of sufficient prejudice, which we expect will ofien be so, that course should be followed."
<line: 3> Rainey v. V/arner, 603 F.3d 189. 201 (3d Cir. 2010) (quoting Stricklund, 466 U.S. at 697).

[TEXT]
<line: 5> Finally, on habeas review, it is not enough that a federal judge would have found counse!
<line: 6> ineffective. The judge must find that the state court's resolution of the IAC issue itself was
<line: 7>  unreasonable, a higher standard:

[TEXT]
<line: 9> The pivotal question is whether the state court's application of the
<line: 10> Strickland standard was unreasonable. This is different from asking
<line: 11> whether defense counsel's performance fell below Stricklad's
<line: 12> standard. Were that the inquiry, the analysis would be no different
<line: 13> than if, for example. this Court were adjudicating a Strickland claim
<line: 14> on direct review of a criminal conviction in a United States district
<line: 15> court. Under AEDPA, though, it is a necessary premise that the two
<line: 16> questions are different. For purposes of s 2254(d)(t). an
<line: 17> wreasonable application of federal law is different from an
<line: 18> incorrecl application of federal law. A state court must be granted a
<line: 19> deference and latitude that are not in operation when the case
<line: 20> involves review under the Strickladd standard itself.

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Harrington, 562 U.S. at 101 (internal quotation marks and citation omitted: emphasis in
<line: 23> original).

[TEXT]
<line: 25> IV.
<line: 26> DISCUSSION

[TEXT]
<line: 28> A. Ground One: Ineffective Assistance of Counsel By Failing To Advise Petitioner
<line: 29> Of His Right To Testify At Trial

[TEXT]
<line: 31> Mr. Rodriguez alleges that his trial counsel. Mr. Feinberg. rendered IAC by "not
<line: 32> advis[ing] Petitioner of his right to testify, nor that the choice whether to testify was ultimately
<line: 33> his to make." (DE 1 at 23 ("IAC-Testify Claim").) In light of the record before me and
<line: 34> governing federal law, for the reasons stated below, I lind that (1) the state court rejection of the
<line: 35> IAC-Testify Claim was neither contrary to nor an unreasonable application of Strickland; and (2)
<line: 36> that Mr. Rodriguez has made no showing of prejudice, i.e., a specific profler of genuinely
<line: 37> exculpatory testimony that would have enhanced his chances of acquittal.

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> 10

[TITLE]
<line: 2> (1) State court ruling on IAC-Testify claim.

[TEXT]
<line: 4> The last reasoned decision on Mr. Rodriguez's IAC-Testify Claim was that of the
<line: 5> Appellate Division on appeal from the denial of PCR. See Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *1.
<line: 6> The Appellate Division *reach[ed] the merits" of, and rejected, the IAC-Testify Claim on Mr.
<line: 7> Rodriguez's appeal from the denial of PCR. Rodriguez. 2015 WL 5038103, at *8.

[TEXT]
<line: 9> The Appellate Division's decision correctly set forth the governing law, including (1) a
<line: 10> criminal defendant's constitutional right to testify and (2) defense counsel's responsibility to
<line: 11> advise his client on whether or not to testify, with explanation of"the tactical advantages and
<line: 12> disadvantages of doing so or of not doing so." Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *8 (internal
<line: 13> citations omitted).

[TEXT]
<line: 15> Next, the Appellate Division considered pertinent parts of the record, summarizing them.
<line: 16> as foilows:

[TEXT]
<line: 18> [Mr.] Feinberg testified at the hearing that he "always talk[ed] to
<line: 19> the defendant about the right to testify," and that his "standard
<line: 20> practice [was] to continue talking during the course of the case to
<line: 21> see whether they want to testify." He added that, at the end of the
<line: 22> State's case, he *typically [sat] down with the client and go over
<line: 23> that." However, he had no independent recollection of doing so
<line: 24> with [Mr.] Rodriguez. He acknowledged that, although he
<line: 25> "routinely" asked the trial judge to voir dire his client on the issue,
<line: 26> he had not done so in this case..

[TEXT]
<line: 28> Id. at *9. The Appeliate Division reasoned that *the PCR judge could have found that Mr.
<line: 29> Feinberg followed his usual practice and advised Mr. Rodriguez of his right to testify, especially
<line: 30> in light of Mr. Rodriguez's failure to certify to the contrary." Id. Alternatively, however, the
<line: 31> Appellate Division determined that the IAC-Testify Claim failed for lack of prejudice: *[E]ven if
<line: 32> we were to find that Rodriguez was not advised of his right to testify, we conclude thal
<line: 33> Rodriguez has not satisfied the second Strickland prong on this issue." Id.

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> 11

[TEXT]
<line: 2> On the Strickland prejudice prong, the state courts considered Mr. Rodriguez's claims.
<line: 3> that (1) he would have testified at trial that his part in the crimes was minimal and due to duress.
<line: 4> (2) he played no part in the pre-murder meeting. (3) he thought the murder victims were being
<line: 5> taken to the park for only a light assault, and (4) he tried unsuccessfully to stop the murders. The
<line: 6> Appellate Division observed, however, that *[t]hose assertions have never been supported by any.
<line: 7> certification." Id. Furthermore, if Mr. Rodriguez had testified, his prior criminal record and his
<line: 8> admission that he had some involvement with the Latin Kings and participated to some degree in
<line: 9> the events of June 29, 1998, would have "opened him up to considerable cross-examination and
<line: 10> would most likely have been counterproductive." Id. For these reasons, the Appellate Division
<line: 11> found "no basis to conclude that there was 'a reasonable probability' that the result of the [trial]
<line: 12> would have been different' had Rodriguez testified as he claims he would have." Id. (citing.
<line: 13> Stricklandl v. Iashington, 466 U.S. 668, 694 (1984). On August 26. 2015. the Appellate Division
<line: 14> aflirmed denial of PCR. Rodrigues. 2015 WL 5038103. at *10. On December 16. 2015. the New
<line: 15> Jersey Supreme Court denied certification. See State . Rodrigues. 127 A.3d 704 (N.J. 2015)

[TEXT]
<line: 17> (2) State Court Rejection Of The IAC-Testify Claim Was Not Unreasonable.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> The state court correctly articulated the Strickland standard and reasonably applied it to.
<line: 20> the facts of Mr. Rodriguez's case. This is not a silent record. During the PCR evidentiary.
<line: 21> hearing. Rodriguez was represented by counsel, Michael G. Paul, Esq. (PCR counsel"). PCR
<line: 22> counsel called Mr. Rodriguez's trial counsel, Mr. Feinberg. as a witness. (DE 17-1 at 91). Mr.
<line: 23> Paul asked trial counsel whether he recalled discussing with Mr. Rodriguez his rightto testify at
<line: 24> trial. (DE 17-1 at 94-95.) Trial counsel replied that althougli he had "no independent recollection
<line: 25> of that, it was his "standard practicc to do it. (Id. at 95 ("I can't say that I have any memory in
<line: 26> doing it in this particular case. We're talking about 11 years ago, approximately 12 years ago").).

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 12

[TEXT]
<line: 2> On cross-examination, he elaborated further:

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Paul Feinberg, Esquire: Well I, in preparation of the case, I always.
<line: 5> talk to the defendant about the right to testify. My standard practice
<line: 6> is to continue talking during the course of the case to see whether.
<line: 7> they want to testify. Then at the end of the State's case when it's.
<line: 8> time to put our case on, I typically sit down with the client to go.
<line: 9> over that. Now do I have a recollection of doing that in this case? I
<line: 10> have no independent recollection of it.

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Assistant Prosecutor: Is it fair to say it was your habit and practice
<line: 13>  as a lawyer practicing for many years in capital cases and other
<line: 14> murder cases to conduct yourself in that manner?

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Mr. Feinberg: Yes, and I believe it should be the practice of every.
<line: 17> lawyer who handles criminal cases.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> (DE 17-1 at 104-05.) Mr. Rodriguez did not testify at the hearing.3

[TEXT]
<line: 21> The only evidence of record, then, that was before the Appellate Division at the time it
<line: 22> rejected the IAC-Testify Claim, was that Trial counsel believed he had informed Mr. Rodriguez.
<line: 23> of his right to testify at trial in accord with his invariable practice. The state court was entitled to
<line: 24> credit counsel's on-the-record representations. The state court's finding that the deficient-
<line: 25> performance prong was not satisfied by those facts was a reasonable application of Strickland.

[TITLE]
<line: 27> (3) Lack of prejudice

[TEXT]
<line: 29> Mr. Rodriguez also has failed to demonstrate prejudice from the alleged error. That is, he
<line: 30> does not specifically point to facts suggesting that he would have offered exculpatory testimony
<line: 31> that had a reasonable probability of altering the result.

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> Mr. Rodriguez, who was represented both at trial and in the PCR proceedings, did not testify to
<line: 34> the contrary, nor did he provide to the state courts any evidence that contradicted his Trial counsel's
<line: 35> sworn testimony. Factually, his claim that counsel failed to advise him rested solely on unsupported
<line: 36> contentions in his supplemental appellate pro se briefs in connection with PCR. (DE 10-6 at 13-14; DE
<line: 37> 10-7 at 15-16.) The lirst time that Mr. Rodriguez ever made these contentions in sworn form was in this
<line: 38> habeas matter, in his February 15, 2017 Declaration In Support Of His Motion For An Evidentiary
<line: 39> Hearing ("Declaration"). (DE 27-2 at 1 (*Trial counsel failed to advise me about my right to testify").)
<line: 40> Neither that Declaration nor anything equivalent was before the state courts. The presumption that this
<line: 41> Court, on habeas review, must defer to reasonable state court fact finding is not overcome.

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> 13

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Of course, every defendant has a right to testily, and an equal and opposite right not to.
<line: 3> Iestify. He cannot do one without waiving the other. See generally United States v. Penycooke.
<line: 4> 65 F.3d 9, 11 (3d Cir. 1995). In any case, therefore, a convicted defendant who has opted for one.
<line: 5> alternative may base a claim on having foregone the other. It is perhaps for this reason that in
<line: 6> such cases, the courts have required a somewhat specific statement of how the delendant's.
<line: 7> testimony might have changed the result..

[TEXT]
<line: 9> Thus, for example, in Palmer r. Hendricks, 592 F.3d 386 (3d Cir. 2010), the Court of
<line: 10> Appeals considered a similar claim of IAC. but found no prejudice. That petitioner stated that he.
<line: 11> had wished to assert a theory of self-defense. one which would have relied on his testifying to his
<line: 12> version of the events. Still, said the court, Palmer had revealed nothing specific "about the facts
<line: 13> to which Palmer would have testified." Id. at 395 (the petition "containfed] no factual matter
<line: 14> regarding Stricklad's prejudice prong'). It was not cnough. said the Court of Appeals. that the
<line: 15> petitioner claimed to have acted in self-defense and wanted to *tell his side of the story." Id..
<line: 16> Without further specificity. the petitioner had not met his burden to demonstrate an enhanced
<line: 17> likelihood of acquittal, in the sense that the testimony would have been "genuinely exculpatory.'
<line: 18> Id. at 395-96. It upheld the denial of the habeas petition without a hearing..

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Mr. Rodriguez's IAC-Testify Clain suffers the same shortcomings. He expresses very
<line: 21> little beyond a generalized desire to tell his side of the story. He is not specific about what his
<line: 22> testimony would have consisted of, but posits that it would have "refuted' the State's case:

[TEXT]
<line: 24> I-wanted to testify and put forth a defense contradicting the testimony of
<line: 25> witnesses from the State who already had credibility problems and multiple.

[ABANDON]
<line: 27> In contrast with this case, the petitioner in Palmer had been denied a hearing in state court as
<line: 28> well, so AEDPA deference did not apply. 592 F.3d at 390, 399-400. On thc other hand, however, Palmer
<line: 29> rejected the petitioner's argument that even in the absence of a factual showing of prejudice, counsel's
<line: 30> failure to advise of the right to testimony was a "structural crror that would mandate automatic reversal
<line: 31> 1.ai 396-97.

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> 14

[TEXT]
<line: 2> criminal convictions, and whose questionable lestimony was the only evidence
<line: 3> against Petitioner. Petitioner's testimony would have been corroborated by Edwin
<line: 4> Diaz, another codefendant who was cooperating with the state and plead guilty
<line: 5> prior to trial. And also by the testimony of Juan DeJesus, a state witness. It cannot
<line: 6> be emphasized enough that Petitioner's testimony was crucial for his defense
<line: 7> because it refutes all evidence presented against him by the State.

[TEXT]
<line: 9> (DE 1 at 23-24.) Mr. Rodriguez does not specify what he would have said, or how his say-so
<line: 10> would have "refuted" the State's case..

[TEXT]
<line: 12> At any rate, there is good reason lo endorse the state court's skepticism that Mr.

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Rodriguez's testimony would have carried the day:

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Rodriguez had a [criminal] record and wouid have been cross-examined on that
<line: 17> basis. His admission that he had some involvement with the Latin Kings and the
<line: 18> events of June 29, 1998 would have opened him up to considerable cross-
<line: 19> examination and would most likely have been counterproductive.

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *9. For these reasons, too, there was "no basis to conclude

[TEXT]
<line: 23> there was a 'reasonable probability' that *the result of the [trial] wouid have been different had

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Rodriguez testified as he claims he would have." Id.

[TEXT]
<line: 27> It is well-settled that a petitioner has the burden of proving specific facts to support an
<line: 28> allegation of ineffective assistance of counsel. Sistrunk . Vaughn, 96 F.3d 666, 671 (3d Cir.
<line: 29> 1996); W/ells v. Petsock, 941 F.2d 253, 259-260 (3d Cir. 1991). The Appellate Division did not
<line: 30> unreasonably apply the governing constitutional standards or unreasonably find the facts when it
<line: 31> found, based on the record before it, that Mr. Rodriguez had not satisfied Strickland's prejudice
<line: 32> prong. Rodrigues. 2015 WL 5038103, at *9.

[TEXT]
<line: 34> On both deficient-performance and prejudice grounds, then, Ground One of the Petition
<line: 35> (IAC-Testify Claim) is denied..

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> Mr. Rodriguez's prior convictions do not seem to be listed in the documents that are before me.
<line: 38> His criminal record was sufficiently serious, however, that it preponderated over mitigating factors in Mr.
<line: 39> Rodriguez's sentencing. (DE 17-5 at 3.).

[ABANDON]
<line: 41> 15

[TITLE]
<line: 2> B. Ground Two: Ineffective Assistance of Counsel - Absenee for Three Days
<line: 3> During Jury Seleetion.

[TEXT]
<line: 5> Mr. Rodriguez alleges that his trial counsel, Mr. Feinberg. rendered IAC by "fail[ing] to
<line: 6> attend sessions of jury selection for three days due to his hospitalization following a heart attack.
<line: 7> Trial counsel failed to arrange substitute counsel for [Pletitioner." (DE 1 at 25 (*IAC-Jury
<line: 8> Selection Claim').) According to Mr. Rodriguez, trial counsel's absence also impaired his
<line: 9> objections to under-representation of Hispanics on the jury (id.). a claim that is discussed
<line: 10> substantively at Section IV.C, infra.

[TEXT]
<line: 12> The trial record confirms that Mr. Feinberg was indeed absent for three days at the outset
<line: 13> of the jury selection process: January 24, 26, and 27, 2000. See Rodrigues. 2015 WL 5038103, at
<line: 14> *6. What went on in those three days. however, was not "jury selection' in the sense of roir dire.
<line: 15> questioning or the exercise of challenges. whether peremptory or for-cause. Rather, duriny those.
<line: 16> three days the trial judge accommodated trial counsel's absence by confining the proceedings to
<line: 17> the distribution and collection of questionnaires. and the grant or denial of hardship excuses. The
<line: 18> record reveals the following:

[TEXT]
<line: 20> On January 24. 2000, the trial judge instructed a group of potential jurors on the jury
<line: 21> selection process and gave a brief overview of the case. In explaining Mr. Feinberg's absence.
<line: 22> the judge told the jury panel:.

[TEXT]
<line: 24> We have had a minor illness of one of our attorneys. and so I am.
<line: 25> working around that. I am attempting to use the lime that we have.
<line: 26> to get your questionnaires filled out. which is time consuming..
<line: 27> [and to] give the attorneys an opportunity to review them so we are.
<line: 28> prepared to question you without wasting a lot of your time.
<line: 29> unnecessarily.

[TEXT]
<line: 31> (DE 12-4 at 11.) The next day, Wednesday, January 26, 2000, the judge similarly instructed.
<line: 32> another group of potential jurors and distributed questionnaires. See Rodriguer, 2015 WL.

[ABANDON]
<line: 34> 16

[ABANDON]

[TEXT]
<line: 3> 5038103, at *6. The judge again told the potential jurors about Mr. Feinberg's illness:

[TEXT]
<line: 5> We experienced a minor illness of onc of the attorneys.
<line: 6> Fortunately, we were able to work around that due to the
<line: 7> professionalism of the attorneys. It was agreed I would work with
<line: 8> you by myself, and for the purpose of getting these questionnaires
<line: 9> filed out, which helps us a lot if the attorneys have access to them
<line: 10> to be able to review them, as well as myself, so we will not be off
<line: 11> schedule by more than a couple of days by virtue of the attorney's
<line: 12> illness.

[TEXT]
<line: 14> I was able to find out this morning it was not serious, so that person
<line: 15> will be able to be back with us on Monday [i.e., January 31. 2000].

[TEXT]
<line: 17> Id.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> On Thursday, January 27, 2o00, the judge distributed to counsel the questionnaires that
<line: 20> had already been filled out, and assured everyone that Mr. Feinberg would be given ample
<line: 21> opportunity to review the questionnaires before proceedings resumed on the afternoon of
<line: 22> Monday, January 31. 2000. (DE 12-5 at 5-6.) The judge also instructed and distributed blank
<line: 23> questionnaires to a fresh batch of potential jurors. The judge again explained that she had begun.
<line: 24> the process of orienting potential jurors and distributing questionnaires to accommodate Mr.
<line: 25> Feinberg's absence. The judge added, *We now know when the attorney will be returning. and
<line: 26> with the agreement of counsel, I am doing the orientation and filling out the questionnaires
<line: 27> without them so as to keep on schedule. (Id. at 19.)

[TEXT]
<line: 29> The trial proceedings resumed the following week, at 1 p.m. on Monday. January 31.
<line: 30> 2000. The record reflects that Mr. Feinberg was present for the remainder of the jury selection.
<line: 31> process. (DE 12-6 at 2, 4 (January 31, 2000); DE 12-7 at 2, 3 (February 1. 2000): DE 12-8 at 2, 3
<line: 32> (February 2, 2000); DE 13-1 at 2, 3 (February 3, 2000); DE 13-2 at 2, 3 (Fcbruary 4. 2000); DE
<line: 33> 13-3 at 2, 3 (February 7. 2000); DE 13-4 at 2, 3 (February 8, 2000).)

[TEXT]
<line: 35> The PCR court convened an evidentiary hearing on Mr. Rodriguez's claim based on the

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 17

[TEXT]
<line: 2> three-day absence of counsel. Mr. Rodriguez was represented by separate counse! in connection
<line: 3> with that hearing. Mr. Feinberg testified. He confirmed that he suffered a heart attack and missed
<line: 4> three day's as a result of his hospitalization. He agreed that the events he missed were the.
<line: 5> completion of written questionnaires and the trial judge's grant of hardship excuses (the
<line: 6> "Hardship/Questionnaire" proceedings). (DE 17-1 at 92-93.) Public defender Andrew Rojas,
<line: 7> Esq., who represented co-defendant Perez, lestified at the hearing that while Mr. Feinberg was
<line: 8> absent, the potential juror questionnaires were collected and reviewed only for the purpose of
<line: 9> screening for hardship excuses. Mr. Rojas testified that the interests of his client. Perez, and
<line: 10> those of Mr. Rodriguez were entirely paralle! with respect to those narrow Hardship.
<line: 11> Questionnaire proceedings. (Id. at 26-28.) Mr. Rodriguez did not testify..

[TEXT]
<line: 13> Based on that evidentiary record, the PCR judge rejected Mr. Rodriguez's IAC-Jury

[TEXT]
<line: 15> Selection Claim:

[TEXT]
<line: 17> Here. unlike State r. McCombs, [81 N.J. 373.] 374 [(1979)]. [Mr.]
<line: 18> Rodriguez was not *left adrift during so crucial a phase of the trial
<line: 19> as the jury selection process." The selection, or more precisely, the
<line: 20> rejection ritual was barren of the challenges inherent in jury
<line: 21> selection. There was no weighing of the worthiness of any
<line: 22> perspective juror. What transpired was a pre-jury selection session.
<line: 23> that was solely designed to eliminate *hardship cases" through the
<line: 24> inspection of the submitted questionnaires. The testimony of Mr.
<line: 25> Feinberg and Mr. Rojas and the trial transcript plainly convey what.
<line: 26> unfolded and the purpose of the protocol utilized. This preliminary
<line: 27> review as described was not a"critical stage" and as a consequence.
<line: 28> there was no transgression of the defendant's "right to counsel.'

[TITLE]
<line: 30> (DE 10-6 at 86.)

[TEXT]
<line: 32> The Appellate Division aflirmed, explaining as follows:

[TEXT]
<line: 34> The PCR judge's factual findings with respect to what occurred
<line: 35> during the limited porlion of jury sclection missed by Feinberg is
<line: 36> fully supported by the record. During those three days, the trial
<line: 37> judge held orientation sessions for prospective jurors and
<line: 38> instructed them lo complete questionnaires to determine whether

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> 18

[TEXT]
<line: 2> their jury service would "impose a severe hardship due to
<line: 3> circumstances which are not likely to change within the following.
<line: 4> year." N.J.$.A. 2B:2010(c). When Feinberg returned, he was
<line: 5> afforded the opportunity to review the questionnaires and
<line: 6> participated in the remainder of jury selection.

[TEXT]
<line: 8> At no time during Feinberg's absence were potential jurors
<line: 9> questioned on other issues or removed peremptorily or for cause.
<line: 10> The facts in this case are significantly different from those in
<line: 11> McCombs, 81 N.J. at 374-79, in which the Supreme Court held that
<line: 12> a defense attorney who did not participate in the entire jury
<line: 13> selection process was deficient.

[TEXT]
<line: 15> Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *7. In short, said the Appellate Division, this was not a critical
<line: 16> stage, but a this *"pre-jury selection session that was solely designed to eliminate 'hardship cases'.
<line: 17> through the inspection of the submitted questionnaires." Id. at *7. For these reasons, the.
<line: 18> Appellate Division found *no merit to Mr. Rodriguez's IAC-Jury Selection Claim. Id.

[TEXT]
<line: 20> To be sure, *[t]he Sixth Amendment guarantees a defendant the right to have counsel.
<line: 21> present at all -critical' stages of the criminal proceedings." Missouri v. Frye. 566 U.S. 134, 140..
<line: 22> 132 S. Ct. 1399. 1405 (2012) (quoting Montejo r. Louisiana. 556 U.S. 778. 786. 129 S. Ct. 2079)
<line: 23> (2009) (quoting United States . II/ade. 388 U.S. 218, 227-28, 87 S. Ct. 1926 (1967). Expressed
<line: 24> that way, however. the principle is general. To warrant habeas relief, U.S. Supreme court
<line: 25> precedent must more pointedly address *the specific question presented by this case." I'oods r.
<line: 26> Donald. 135 S. Ct. 1372, 1377 (2015) (quoting Lopes r. Smith, 574 U.S.. 135 S. Ct. 1. 4
<line: 27> (2014)).

[TEXT]
<line: 29> When the Supreme Court said"specific," it meant it. In I'oods, supra, the Supreme Court
<line: 30> overturned the affirmance of federal habeas relief based on counsel's absence during trial.
<line: 31> testimony concerning the petitioner's codefendants. Supreme Court case law established that the

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> The Petitioner's argument was that, although he claimed not to have been directly involved in the
<line: 34> shooting. the charges against hin included felony murder and aiding and abetting. Thus, he argued, the.

[ABANDON]
<line: 36>  19

[TEXT]
<line: 2> testimony of a government witness was a "critical stage," but the Supreme Court had not
<line: 3> specifically addressed the issue of testimony "about other defendants." 135 S. Ct. at 1377.
<line: 4> (emphasis in original). Under AEDPA, 28 U.S.C. g 2254(d), cited supra, a state court decision is
<line: 5> not "contrary to" Supreme Court precedent because it reached the opposite result in
<line: 6> circumstances that were merely "similar." Id. To put it another way, Woods found that the Court
<line: 7> of Appeals had framed the "critical stage"' issue at "too high a level of generality." Id. Woods
<line: 8> thus held that the state court's application of Sixth Amendment precedents was neither contrary.
<line: 9> to, nor an unreasonable application of, U.S. Supreme Court precedent..

[TEXT]
<line: 11> I have found no U.S. Supreme Court case addressing the "specific question" presented by
<line: 12> this case: whether distribution of questionnaires and granting hardship excuses is a "critical
<line: 13> stage" requiring the presence of counsel.' That in itself is sufficient to doom the claim under.

[TEXT]
<line: 15> testimony of this government witness was a critical phase of the trial, as to which prejudice from his
<line: 16> counsel's absence would be presumed.

[TEXT]
<line: 18> Pretrial proceedings identified as "critical"' for Sixth Amendment purposes include "arraignments,
<line: 19> postindictment interrogations, postindictment lineups, and the entry of a guilty plea." Frye, 566 U.S. at
<line: 20> 140 (citing Supreme Court precedents). Trial-related proceedings identified as critical, because
<line: 21> "substantial rights"' of the accused are affected, include arraignment, competency hearings, a post0-
<line: 22> indictment lineup, a preliminary hearing, a plea hearing, closing arguments, and sentencing. Mempa v.
<line: 23> Rhay, 389 U.S. 128, 134, 88 S. Ct. 254, 257 (1967). See also Gardner v. Florida, 430 U.S. 349, 358
<line: 24> (1977) (sentencing); United States v. Roy, 855 F.3d 1133, 1147 (11th Cir. 2017) (summarizing existing
<line: 25> law).

[TEXT]
<line: 27> The absence of positive Supreme Court authority is sufficient for present purposes under
<line: 28> AEDPA. I note in addition, however, that analogous Supreme Court authority tends to suggest that the.
<line: 29> Court would answer the question posed by this case in the negative. In Rushen v. Spain, 464 U.S. 114,.
<line: 30> 121, 1004 S. Ct. 453, 457 (1983), a juror answered during voir dire that she had no prior knowledge of
<line: 31> facts relevant to the case. The evidence, however, jogged her memory; when an uncharged murder was
<line: 32> introduced in evidence, she realized that the victim had been a childhood friend. During trial, the juror
<line: 33> went to the judge's chambers and, ex parte, informed him that her voir dire answers had been inaccurate
<line: 34> She stated to the judge that her deliberations would not be biased by that knowledge. The encounter was
<line: 35> revealed only later. On a petition for a writ of habeas corpus, the defendant argued that his Sixth
<line: 36> Amendment right to have counsel present (as well as his right to be present personally) had been violated
<line: 37> by the ex parte conversation, requiring reversal of his conviction per se, without further inquiry into.
<line: 38> prejudice. The U.S. Supreme Court disagreed, and subjected this claim to the usual  2254(d) deference
<line: 39> and a harmless-error analysis. It upheld the conviction based on post-trial factual findings, after a hearing,
<line: 40> that the juror's ex parte exchange with the judge did not prejudice the defendant..

[TEXT]
<line: 2> AEDPA. I note in addition, however, that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has
<line: 3> dealt with this issue; it has held explicitly *that hardship questioning is not a part of voir dire--
<line: 4> and thus not a critical stage of the trial during which the parties and counsel must be present."
<line: 5> United States v. Greer, 285 F.3d 158, 168 (2d Cir. 2002) (citing Second Circuit case law).

[TEXT]
<line: 7> The state court, considering the "critical stage' (or "crucial stage") issue, cited State v.
<line: 8> McCombs, 81 N.J. 373, 408 A.2d 425 (1979), which cited federal as well as state constitutional
<line: 9> precedents. In distinguishing McCombs, the state court did not unreasonably apply U.S. Supreme.
<line: 10> Court precedent. In McCombs, defense counsel had been excused before trial and was absent for
<line: 11> the entire voir dire process of jury selection. The New Jersey Supreme Court emphasized that
<line: 12> what is "critical" about the critical stage is the selection of an impartial jury, through the process.
<line: 13> of voir dire questioning (even if done by the judge). In distinguishing McCombs and finding that.
<line: 14> counsel's absence did not impair the selection of an impartial jury, the state court here did not
<line: 15> run afoul of Sixth Amendment standards or Supreme Court case law. And "[w]here the ' "precise.
<line: 16> contours"' of [a] right remain ' "unclear,"' state courts enjoy 'broad discretion' in their.
<line: 17> adjudication of a prisoner's claims." Woods, 135 S. Ct. at 1377.8.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> The state court here permissibly found that there was no impairment of the right to have
<line: 20> counsel participate in the selection of an impartial jury. The Hardship / Questionnaire process --
<line: 21> the only time during which Mr. Feinberg was absent -- was not a critical stage of the
<line: 22> proceedings. It did not weed out jurors based on partiality. It did not require counsel's exercise of.
<line: 23> strategy or advocacy on Mr. Rodriguez's behalf. In short, this process did not implicate the

[ABANDON]
<line: 25> Quoting White v. Woodall, 572 U.S. _, 134 S.Ct. 1697, 1705 (2014) (quoting Lockyer v.
<line: 26> Andrade, 538 U.S. 63, 76, 123 S. Ct. 1166 (2003), in turn quoting Harmelin v. Michigan, 501 U.S. 957,
<line: 27> 998, 11I S. Ct. 2680 (1991) (KENNEDY, J., concurring in part and in judgment)).

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 21

[TEXT]
<line: 2> selection of an impartial jury. A juror who had a sufficient hardship was simply waailuble to
<line: 3> participate for the duration of the trial. Such a juror could not feasibly serve and was excused. for
<line: 4> reasons having nothing to do with the merits of the case or the juror's attitudes towards it. And of
<line: 5> course the questionnaires themselves, to the extent they bore on the exercise of peremptory
<line: 6> challenges, were made available for counse!'s inspection before any peremptory challenges were
<line: 7> exercised.9

[TEXT]
<line: 9> The state court's application of federal law was reasonable. Moreover. the state court
<line: 10> reasonably found as a matter of fact that nothing critical requiring the input of counsel occurred
<line: 11> in those preliminary sessions, and nothing before me is sufficient to overcome the deference that
<line: 12> I am required to give such a finding

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Federal habeas relief on Ground Two of the Petition (the lAC-Jury Selection Claim) is
<line: 15> therefore denied.

[TEXT]
<line: 17> C. Ground Four: Diseriminatory Exclusion of Hispanic Jurors

[TEXT]
<line: 19> Mr. Rodriguez claims that Hispanics were unconstitutionally excluded from the venire
<line: 20> pool (referred to as "Array Composition Claim") and that the State "us[ed] peremptory
<line: 21> challenges in a discriminatory manner' during jury selection (referred to, for simplicity. as the
<line: 22> Batson Claim"). (DE 1 at 27.) Although the two aspects of the claim are sometimes conllated in
<line: 23> the papers, they are distinct, and I discuss them separately. Both aspects of this claim will be
<line: 24> denied.

[ABANDON]
<line: 26> I add that there are no facts in this record to support Mr. Rodriguez's claim that something about
<line: 27> the hardship excuse process bore upon, or impaired him from raising. a claim that Hispanics were
<line: 28> systematically excluded from service. Such a claim was in fact raised and rejected. The hardship excuse
<line: 29> process preceded the exercise of peremptory challenges, for which Mr. Feinberg was present. The claims
<line: 30> relating to the ethnic composition of the venire and the allegedly discriminatory' exercise of peremptory.
<line: 31> challenges are discussed substantively in Section IV.C, infra.

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> 22

[TITLE]
<line: 2> 1. Ground Four's Array Composition Claim.

[TITLE]
<line: 4> a. State court rulings.

[TEXT]
<line: 6> During trial, Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Romero joined in several arguments pertinent to the
<line: 7> issues now raised in Ground Four, including a challenge to the cthnic composition of the jury
<line: 8> array. The trial judge acknowledged the prosecutor's argument that the challenge came too late.
<line: 9> in that selection was underway. But the judge discussed and rejected the challenge on the merits.
<line: 10> explaining that the Essex County's array selection process had previous!y withstood
<line: 11> constitutional scrutiny. The court stated that *[t]he fact that a particular pool of jurors might or
<line: 12>  might not meet with the defendant's requirements or expectations as to the cthnic makeup is not
<line: 13> relevant as long as the system is as fair as it can be humanly made." (DE 10-2 at 45.).

[TEXT]
<line: 15> On direct appeal, Mr. Rodriguez asserted the jury-array component of his claim, but the.
<line: 16> Appellate Division rejected it. (DE 10-3 at 26-27.) In doing so, the court incorporated by.
<line: 17> reference its discussion of co-defendant Romero's similar claim in a prior written decision. (Id.
<line: 18> at 27: DE 10-2 at 43-49.) Romero had asserted that counse! rendered IAC by *fail(ing] to
<line: 19> effectively challenge the [county's] jury selection process on the ground that it unfairly excluded
<line: 20> Hispanics." (DE 10-2 at 43.) The Appellate Division rejected Mr. Romero's claim, citing prior
<line: 21> state Supreme Court case law finding that Essex County's jury-array selection process was
<line: 22> constitutional. (Id. at 45 (citing State v. Gilmore. 103 N.J. 508, 511 A.2d 1150 (N.J. 1986).) See
<line: 23> also State v. McDougald, 120 N.J. 523, 549-50 (1990); State r. Ramseur, 106 N.J. 123, 212-38.
<line: 24> 524 A.2d 188 (1987).10

[TEXT]
<line: 26> On appeal from the denial of PCR, the Appellate Division found no merit in Petitioner's

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 10
<line: 29> Rumseur was disapproved on other grounds in Jones : United States, 527 U.S. 373, 383, 119 S.
<line: 30> Ct. 2090, 2099 (1999). Lisis for selection of petit and grand jurors are drawn in the same manner.

[ABANDON]
<line: 32> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 2> PCR Jury-IAC challenge to the jury array. The issue had already been rejected on direct appeal.
<line: 3> Mr. Rodriguez argues that he was raising a distinct issue, based on his counsel's threc-day.
<line: 4> absence.'l The Appellate Division rejected the notion that Mr. Feinberg's absence had prejudiced
<line: 5> the jury-array challenge in any way. This claim, the Appellate Division held, did not satisfy
<line: 6> either Strickland prong:

[TEXT]
<line: 8> As previously noted, Feinberg did object to the ethnic composition
<line: 9> of the jury array, and the trial judge rejected the argument on the.
<line: 10> merits. Rodriguez has not demonstrated that Feinberg's objection
<line: 11> would have been successlul had it been raised earlier in jury
<line: 12> selection process, during the brief period of time he was absent. As
<line: 13> a consequence, he cannol satisfy the second Stricklamd prong, even
<line: 14> if he could have satisfied the first.

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, at *8. The Appellate Division determined that Mr. Rodriguez's

[TEXT]
<line: 18> PCR Jury-IAC Claim was without merit as a matter of fact and law. Id.

[TITLE]
<line: 20> b. Diseussion

[TEXT]
<line: 22> The Sixth Amendment requires that no distinctive group be systematically excluded from.
<line: 23> the pool or array from which juries are selected. See Taylor v. Louisiana, 419 U.S. 522, 530
<line: 24> (2009). The state court (and the Romero opinion it cited. DE 10-2 at 45) noted that Essex.
<line: 25> County's method of compiling the venire. or juror source list. was upheld against constitutional
<line: 26> challenge in Gilmore, MeDougald, and State v. Ramseur, supra.'? Ramseur himself revived that

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 11
<line: 29> Mr. Rodriguez argued that his jury-related PCR claim was "fundamentally different from the.
<line: 30> claim raised in the direct appeal" because it was based on counsel's three-day absence, *based on trial
<line: 31> counsel's ineffectiveness in failing 1o procure [counsel] coverage for the [juror] questionnaire proceeding
<line: 32> during [Mr. Feinberg's]-hospitalization; due to counsel's-failure, defendant had no opportunity to raise a
<line: 33> timely objection to the racial makeup of the panel." Rodrigues, 2015 WL 5038103, a1 *8 (emphasis added
<line: 34> in original). These grounds appear lo relate to the challenge to thc jury array. Mr. Feinberg was not absent
<line: 35> for the exercise of peremplory challenges..
<line: 36> 12
<line: 37> Indeed, these state decisions are e fortiori cases. Gilmore, relied on by the state court, emphasized
<line: 38> that in this area, federal constitutional standards established only the "floor of minimum constitutional
<line: 39> protection"; the State Constitutional right to a jury drawn from a representative cross-section of the
<line: 40> community affords "greater protection to our citizens' individual rights than accorded them under the
<line: 41> federal constitution." 130 N.J. at 523~24..

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> 24

[TEXT]
<line: 2> challenge in a federal habeas petition. the denial of which was upheld, after substantia! factual
<line: 3> and statistical analysis, by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Ramseur v. Beyer.
<line: 4> 983 F.2d 1215, 1229-35 (3d Cir. 1992).

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Viewed substantively, the state court rulings are well supported by case law. They are not
<line: 7> contrary to Supreme Court case law..

[TEXT]
<line: 9> Viewing the claim as one of IAC, I cannot find deficient performance or prejudice.
<line: 10> Counsel did raise this challenge to the array. The challenge was rejected by the trial court. but if
<line: 11> the trial court's ruling was wrong, the claim would not be one of IAC, but rather of ordinary
<line: 12> error, correctable on appeal. As it happens. on direct appeal the Appellate Division rejected that
<line: 13> very claim of error, i.e., that Hispanics had been systematically or unfairly excluded from the
<line: 14> jury pool. Particularly given the strong prior case law upholding the county's system for.
<line: 15> summoning jurors, I cannot find that counsel's representation fell short of acceptable
<line: 16> professional standards. I can find no error. moreover. in the Appellate Division's finding that Mr.
<line: 17> Feinberg's initial absence had no effect on the jury-array challenge.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> There is nothing here sufficient to rebut the presumption of correctness of the Appellate
<line: 20> Division's decision upholding the trial judge's rejection of the challenge to the ethnic
<line: 21> composition of the jury array. Rodriguez, 2015 WL 5038103. at *8. Mr. Rodriguez has not
<line: 22> rebutted the presumption by clear and convincing evidence, and he has not shown that this
<line: 23> determination was unreasonable in light of the evidence presented. See 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(d)(2) &
<line: 24> (e)(1).

[TEXT]
<line: 26> Ground Four's Array Composition Claim is therefore denied.

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 2. Ground Four Batson Claim:.

[ABANDON]
<line: 30> 25

[TEXT]
<line: 2> The State is constitutionally prohibited from using its peremptory challenges to exclude
<line: 3> jurors on the basis of race or ethnicity. The three-part test to determine whether a perenptory
<line: 4> challenge is unconstitutionally based on race was set forth by the Supreme Court in Batson ..
<line: 5> Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986). First, a defendant must show that a peremptory challenge has.
<line: 6> been exercised on the basis of race. Second, if that showing has been made, the prosecution must
<line: 7> offer a race-neutral basis for striking the juror in question. Third. the trial court must determine
<line: 8> whether the defendant has shown purposeful discrimination. See id. at 96-98; accord United
<line: 9> States v. Milan, 304 F.3d 273, 281 (3d Cir. 2002). cert. dlenied, 538 U.S. 1024 (2003). State
<line: 10> constitutional law is parallel. See State r. Gilmore. 103 N.J. 508. 522. 511 A.2d 1150. 1157
<line: 11> (1986) (We observe that under Batson's interpretation of the Equal Protection Clause of the.
<line: 12> Fourtcenth Amendment . . . the United States Constitution would compel the result that we reach
<line: 13> on independent state grounds").

[TITLE]
<line: 15> a. State court rulings

[TEXT]
<line: 17> At trial. the judge rejected the chailenge of Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Romero (DE 12-2 at
<line: 18> 45-49) to the State's alleged!y discriminatory exercise of peremptory challenges to exclude
<line: 19> Hispanics and African-Americans. The defense, the judge ruled. had not shown a substantia!
<line: 20> likelihood that the State had exercised peremptory challenges based on assumptions about group.
<line: 21> bias (illegitimate) rather than situation-specific bias evinced by a particular juror (legitimate). In
<line: 22> particular, the judge found no indicia of discrimination. As the court found, the prosecution had.
<line: 23> not struck all, or most, African Americans and persons with Hispanic surnames. In the judge's
<line: 24> estimation, there was no indication of racial or ethnic exclusion. because all of the jurors seated
<line: 25> at that point were either African American or Hispanic, with one probable exception.'3 The judge.

[ABANDON]
<line: 27> 13

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> Onc juror by the name of Teixera, counsel secmed to agree, was likely of Portuguese extraction.

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 26

[TEXT]
<line: 2> further observed that while the prosecution had excluded two Hispanic jurors, the defense had
<line: 3> done the same. (DE 10-2 at 48; DE 12-2 at 46.) The challenge failed, then, for ailure to make
<line: 4> the prima facie showing required by state case law (which. for present purposes, is identical to
<line: 5> Batson).

[TEXT]
<line: 7> On direct appeal, Mr. Rodriguez argued that his trial counsel's "acceptance of the jury.
<line: 8> panel as satisfactory and [counsel's] failure to exhaust defendant's peremptory challenges
<line: 9> deprived him of his constitutional right to effective assistance of counsel, because the issue was
<line: 10> not preserved for direct appeal." (DE 10-3 at 27.) The Appellate Division disagreed (id. at 27).
<line: 11> citing its written opinion disposing of co-defendant Mr. Romero's similar claim (*Romero Jury-
<line: 12> IAC Claim"). (Id.; DE 10-2 at 45-49.)

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Mr. Romero had asserted that counsel rendered lAC because the State used its.
<line: 15> peremptory challenges to exclude only African-Americans and Hispanics. in violation of his
<line: 16> constitutional right to an impartial jury. He also claimed that his own counsel was ineffective for
<line: 17> failing to pursue a challenge. (Id. at 45-46.) The Appellate Division rejected his claim, lirst
<line: 18> correctly summarizing the governing law under Batson, suprar:.

[TEXT]
<line: 20> An impartial jury does not reguire the systematic inclusion of
<line: 21> cognizable groups, but does preclude the State's use of peremptory
<line: 22> challenges to unreasonably restrict the possibility that a petit [jury]
<line: 23> will comprise a representative cross-section of the community...

[TEXT]
<line: 25> The Sixth Amendment['s] guarantee[] [of] ... trial by an impartial
<line: 26> jury ... prohibits selective removal of jurors who are members of a
<line: 27> cognizable group on the basis oftheir presumed group bias ..

[TEXT]
<line: 29> There is a rebuttable presumption that the prosecution has.
<line: 30> exercised its peremplory challenges on permissible grounds. Once
<line: 31> defendant has made a timely challenge to the prosecution's use of
<line: 32> peremptory challenges, the defendant must make a prima facie
<line: 33> showing that those challenges were exercised on grounds that were
<line: 34> constitutionally inpermissible. This requires a showing that the
<line: 35> potential jurors wholly or disproportionately excluded were

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 27

[TEXT]
<line: 2> members of a cognizable group within the meaning of the
<line: 3> representative cross-seclion rule..

[TEXT]
<line: 5> The defendant then must show that there is a substantial likelihood
<line: 6> that the peremptory challenges resulting in the exclusion were
<line: 7>  based on assumptions about group bias rather than any indication
<line: 8> of situation-specific bias..

[TEXT]
<line: 10> Once the defendant establishes a prima facie case, the burden shifts
<line: 11> to the prosecutor to show evidence that the peremptory challenges.
<line: 12> were justified based on concern for bias specific to the situation..

[TEXT]
<line: 14> (DE 10-2 at 46 (internal quotations and citations omitted).) The Appellate Division held that the.
<line: 15> Romero Jury-IAC Claim had *no basis." (Id. at 48-49.)

[TEXT]
<line: 17> In so ruling, the Appellate Division referred favorably to the trial judge's finding that the
<line: 18> defense had not met the second prong of a prima facie claim of constitutionally impermissible.
<line: 19> peremptory challenges -- i.e., a substantial likelihood that the peremptory challenges were based!
<line: 20> on assumptions of group bias rather than bias specific to that juror. (Idl. at 48.) This suggests that
<line: 21> counsel's failure to prevail on the Batson claim did not result from deficient performance, and in
<line: 22> any event was not prejudicial, because the claim had no reasonable probability of success. The
<line: 23> Appellate Division reasonably decided that the trial court was correct in finding that the
<line: 24> peremptory challenges displayed no pattern or indicia of discrimination.

[TEXT]
<line: 26> In PCR proceedings, Mr. Rodriguez contended that trial counsel "was constitutionally.
<line: 27> ineffective for failing to object to the State's systematic elimination of Hispanics from the jury
<line: 28> panel during jury selection." (DE 10-6 at 77 (*PCR Jury-IAC Claim").) Given that the Appellate.
<line: 29> Division on direct appeal had disposed of Mr. Romero's challenge to the same jury selection
<line: 30> process, the PCR judge found that New Jersey Rule of Court 3:22-5'4 barred Mr. Rodriguez's

[ABANDON]
<line: 32> 11
<line: 33> That Rule provides that "[a] prior adjudication upon the merits of any ground for relief is
<line: 34> conclusive whether made in the procecdings resulting in the conviction or in any post-conviction.
<line: 35> proceeding brought pursuant to this rule or prior to the adoption thereof, or in any appeal taken from such.
<line: 36> procecdings.

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> 28

[TITLE]
<line: 2> PCR Jury-IAC Claim. (Id. at 78)

[TEXT]
<line: 4> The Appellate Division upheld this portion of the PCR rulings on the PCR appeal. It held
<line: 5> that the trial judge's account of the limited scope of proceedings during Feinberg's absence was
<line: 6> fully supported by the record. No peremptory challenges were implicated in this *pre-jury
<line: 7> selection session that was solely designed to eliminate hardship cases' through the inspection or.
<line: 8> the submitted questionnaires." Rodriguez, 2015 WL 5038103 at *7. The conclusion that this was.
<line: 9> not a "critical stage," it held, was legally sound. Id.

[TITLE]
<line: 11> b. Discussion

[TEXT]
<line: 13> Ground Four's Batson Claim invokes the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments. Mr.
<line: 14> Rodriguez argues that his counsel rendered IAC by failing to contest the State's use of
<line: 15> peremptory challenges to exclude Hispanics or African-Americans from the jury. (DE 1 at 27.)
<line: 16> That claim fails on the merits. The state courts' application of Strickland and Batson standards to.
<line: 17> the pertinent facts was objectively reasonable.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> Strickland's deficient-performance prong is not met. for several reasons. First. Mr.
<line: 20> Feinberg did make a Batson-style objection at trial. See supra. Second, this claim was fully.
<line: 21> litigated at trial and on direct appeal. (DE 12-2 at 44-49: DE 10-2 at 43-49.) Thus. I sec no basis.
<line: 22> to find that counsel failed to act in this regard. Third, the state courts' rulings wvere neither an
<line: 23> unreasonable application of clearly established federal law nor an unreasonable determination of
<line: 24> the facts. The trial court, faced by a challenge, followed Batson standards (citing Gilmore), and
<line: 25> made reasonable findings that no patiern of discrimination was established. See Miller-El v..
<line: 26> Dretke, 545 U.S. 231. 240 (2005) (applying presumption of correctness under s 2254(e)(1) to
<line: 27> state court's factual findings regarding Batson claim).

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 29

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Mr. Rodriguez suggests that he suffered prejudice or a denial of due process because his
<line: 3> counsel's failure to exhaust all peremptories impaired his assertion of the Batson issue on appeal.
<line: 4> No such impairment appears in the record. What doomed the Batson claim was the trial court's
<line: 5> finding that the pattern of prosecution challenges did not establish discrimination.

[TEXT]
<line: 7> On direct appeal, the Appellate Division correctly applied Gilmore, the state-law
<line: 8> equivalent of Batson. (DE 10-2 at 46-47.) The state appellate court agreed with the trial court's
<line: 9> ruling on the Gilmore issue and noted that Mr. Rodriguez seemingly conceded that the trial judge
<line: 10> decided it correctly. (DE 10-2 at 48.)

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Consistent with the state court findings, and my review' of the record. I likewise conclude
<line: 13> that Mr. Rodriguez's Batson-related challenge, whether viewed substantively or as an IAC claim.
<line: 14> is meritless. The state courts applied the proper analyses. Mr. Rodriguez failed to demonstrate
<line: 15> that the peremptory challenges were exercised to exclude minority representation from the jury.
<line: 16> Nor has he now demonstrated, as required by $ 2254(d). that the actions of the state courts
<line: 17> "resulted in a decision that was contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly
<line: 18> established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States," or "resulted
<line: 19> in a decision that was based on an unreasonable determination of the facts in light of the
<line: 20> evidence presented in the State court proceeding."

[TEXT]
<line: 22> "Because a convicted defendant must satisfy both prongs of the Strickland test [i.e..
<line: 23> deficient performance and prejudice]. failure to establish either deficient performance or
<line: 24> prejudice makes it unnecessary to examine the other prong." United Stales r. Manamela, 612 F.
<line: 25> App'x 151. 154 (3d Cir. 2015) (citing Strickland, 466 U.S. at 699). Here, Petitioner established
<line: 26> neither, as the stale courts reasonably found under a correcl application of the governing
<line: 27> Strickland precedent and the underlying Batson standards.

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 30

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Habeas relief on the Bason component of Ground Four is therefore denied..

[TITLE]
<line: 4> D. Ground Three: Failure To Excuse Juror Thirteen During Trial.

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Ground Three, while it discusses a few jurors, centers on juror number thirteen. Mr.
<line: 7> Rodriguez claims that *Ij]uror number thirteen was followed and intimidated by four people
<line: 8> from the audience, while alone." He also claims that *jurors fourtecn and eleven were
<line: 9> approached by a stranger who attempted to speak with them about the case. This incident
<line: 10> exacerbated juror thirteen's safety concerns." (DE 1 at 26-27.) He continues that the State "used
<line: 11> juror thirteen's fear to [its] advantage during summation and made unfair conments inferring
<line: 12> that the defense may be responsible for what occurred." (Id. ("Impartial Jury Claim").) The
<line: 13> result. he says, was denial of his right to an impartia! jury..

[TITLE]
<line: 15> 1.State court rulings

[TEXT]
<line: 17> During trial, on February 18, 2000, the judge announced that three jurors had told a
<line: 18> sheriff s officer that someone from the audience had attempted to speak to them. The judge
<line: 19> prudently determined that she should question the jurors, and did so. Juror fourteen reported that
<line: 20> when she and juror eleven were leaving the courthouse the day before, someone from the
<line: 21> courtroom audience walked up behind them and asked: *What do you think?" Juror fourleen did
<line: 22> not respond, and no more was said. Juror fourteen believed that this brief incident would not
<line: 23> affect her ability to be fair and impartial. (DE 10-2 at 22-23.) Juror eleven's account was parallel.
<line: 24> except that she recalled juror fourteen responding"I don't know nothing." Juror cleven, too.
<line: 25> believed this brief encounter would not prevent her from being a fair juror. (Id. at 23.)

[TEXT]
<line: 27> The judge also questioned juror thirteen. Juror thirteen explained that he had been
<line: 28> "followed by four people" who crossed the street each time he did. Those people *kind of
<line: 29> laughed and joked as [if] to intimidate me. That's what the intention was." (Id.) Juror thirteen

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 31

[TEXT]
<line: 2> recognized the individuals following him as people who had been in the courtroom audience that
<line: 3> morning. (Id. at 24.) He said he thought it was a scare tactic, to let him know he was in danger.
<line: 4> He stated that perhaps more juror security would be desirable. "only because I know that there
<line: 5> was a lactic that was executed upon me when I was alone." (Id.) He added: *Let's put it this way..
<line: 6> I don't like being out in that hall when we're waiting." (Id.) However, he vehemently denied that.
<line: 7> he experienced a level of discomfort or fear that would prevent him being a fair and impartial
<line: 8> juror. (Id. ("What's going on with the trial and what people are sitting here are two different
<line: 9> things, and the people that are sitting here. I don't know who they are. what their allegiance is. I
<line: 10> know nothing at all).) The judge asked again: *Do you feel you can be a fair and impartial.
<line: 11>  juror?" Juror thirteen answered: "Absolutely." (Id.) The judge instructed all three jurors she
<line: 12> questioned that they were not to discuss the matter with the other jurors. (Id.)

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Defense counsel raised no issue with continuing to seat jurors eleven and fourteen. since
<line: 15> being approached did not seem to bother them at all. Counsel for Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Romero
<line: 16> asked the trial judge to excuse juror thirteen. however. saying he was "paranoid." (Id.) The trial
<line: 17>  judge denied the defendants' request to dismiss juror thirteen: instructed the cntire jury as to how.
<line: 18> to treat approaches from outsiders; and instituted additional measures to keep the jurors.
<line: 19> separated from the spectators. (Id.; DE 14-5 at 105-06.).

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Mr. Rodriguez and his co-defendant Mr. Romero raised the Impartial Jury Claim on.
<line: 22> direct appeal. (DE 10-2 at 22-25.) The Appellate Division rejected the claim, correctly citing the
<line: 23> governing Sixth Amendment federal law that *the accused has a constitutional right to a trial by
<line: 24> an impartial jury," which *means that a defendant is cntitled to a jury free of outside influences."
<line: 25> (DE 10-2 at 25 (internal citations omitted).) Citing state case law (which is consistent with
<line: 26> federal standards), the Appellate Division noted that *[t]he test for determining whether irregular

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 32

[TEXT]
<line: 2> influences on jurors merit a new trial is whether it *could have a lendency to influence the jury in
<line: 3> arriving at its verdict in a manner inconsistent with the legal proofs and the court's charge.'" (Id.
<line: 4> (internal citations omitted).) Applying those legal principles, the Appellate Division decided that.
<line: 5> the trial judge had "acted within her discretion' in denying the request to excuse juror thirleen.
<line: 6> The Appcllate Division explained that the record did not support the claim that juror thirteen was
<line: 7> placed in such fear that he would or had been influenced:

[TEXT]
<line: 9> [The defendant] speculates that the juror was influenced by fear to
<line: 10> find him guilty on all counts. However, influence cannot be
<line: 11> inferred merely because that was the verdict. As juror thirteen
<line: 12> made clear, he did not get any message which way the outsiders
<line: 13> might have wanted to influence him, if at all, or, as he said, what
<line: 14> their "allegiance was." The incident was without content, and was
<line: 15> related to the trial only because he recognized the people as
<line: 16> spectators. He was prompted to bring it to the attention of the
<line: 17> judge only to support additional protective measures for the jury.
<line: 18> [!]n this regard[,] no error "clearly capable of producing an unjust
<line: 19> result" occurred in this context. R. 2:10-2.

[TEXT]
<line: 21> (DE 10-2 at 27.) The Appellate Division determined that the Impartial Jury Claim was meritless
<line: 22> as a matter of fact and law. On September 23, 2004, the New Jersey Supreme Court denied
<line: 23> certification. State r. Rodriguez, 859 A.2d 692 (N.J. 2004).

[TITLE]
<line: 25> 2.Diseussion

[TEXT]
<line: 27> The Sixth Amendment guarantees every criminal defendant "the right to a ... trial[ ] by an
<line: 28> impartial jury." U.S. Const. amend. VI. Complementing that right are the protections afforded by.
<line: 29> the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause, which have *long demanded that, if a jury is
<line: 30> to be provided the defendant, regardless of whether the Sixth Amendment requires it, the jury
