<line: 31> must stand impartial and indifferent to the extent commanded by the Sixth Amendment."
<line: 32> Morgan v. Illinois, 504 U.S. 719, 727 (1992); Sheppard v. Maxwell, 384 U.S. 333. 362 (1966)
<line: 33> (the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees each criminal defendant the right to a trial by an

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> 33

[TEXT]
<line: 2> impartial jury free of outside influences). See also State r. WVilliams, 459 A.2d 641 (N.J. 1983)
<line: 3> (*it has long been recognized under the federal Constitution that a defendant is entitled to a jury
<line: 4> that is free of outside influences and will decide the case according to the evidence and
<line: 5> arguments presented in court in the course of the criminal trial itself').

[TEXT]
<line: 7> The applicable U.S. Supreme Court precedents governing third party contact with a jury
<line: 8> are Remmer v. United States, 347 U.S. 227 (1954) (Remumer T), Remmer r. United States, 350
<line: 9> U.S. 377 (1956) (*Remmer IF), and Smith r. Phillips, 455 U.S. 209 (1982).

[TEXT]
<line: 11> If allegations of jury bias involve a third party's contact with a juror during a trial about
<line: 12> the matter pending before the jury, the contact is deemed presumptively prejudicial to the
<line: 13> defendant. Remmer I, 347 U.S. at 229; see also United States v. I/ega. 285 F.3d 256, 266 (3d Cir..
<line: 14> 2002).'5 However, this presumption of prejudice is not conclusive. J'ega, 285 F.3d a1 266 (citing.
<line: 15> Remmer I, 347 U.S. at 229). The trial court must conduct a hearing to *determine the
<line: 16> circumstances. the impact thereof upon the juror, and whether or not [the contact] was
<line: 17> prejudicial, in a hearing with all interested parties permitted to participate.** Remmer I. 347 U.S.
<line: 18> at 230. The government has the burden of rebutting the presumption by showing that the "contact.
<line: 19> with the juror was harmless to the defendant.* Id. at 229-30; see also I/ega, 285 F.3d at 266
<line: 20> (government must prove that the improper communication did not and will not prejudice the.
<line: 21> defendant). *If after [the] hearing [ihe incident] is found to be harmful." the tria! court should
<line: 22> grant a new trial. Remer I, 347 U.S. at 229-30.

[ABANDON]
<line: 24> 15
<line: 25> *In a criminal case, any private communication, contact. or tampering directiy or indirectly, with
<line: 26> a juror during a trial about the matter pending before the jury is ... deemed presumptively prejudiciat, ir
<line: 27> not made in pursuance of known rules of the court and the instructions and directions of the court made
<line: 28> during the trial, with full knowledge of the partics." Vega, 285 F.3d at 266 (quoting Renmer I, 347 U.S.
<line: 29> at 229).

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 34

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Remmer I's rebuttable presumption applies only to a "direct communication [about the
<line: 3> matter pending before the jury] between a juror and a third party during deliberations." United
<line: 4> States v. Console, 13 F.3d 641, 666 (3d Cir. 1993) (distinguishing between the cireumstances
<line: 5> warranting Remmer I's presumption of prejudice and those warranting Smith' s actual prejudice.
<line: 6> analysis). Accord Vega, 285 F.3d at 266 (citing Ialdorf'r. Shnta, 3 F.3d 705, 710 (3d Cir. 1993)
<line: 7> and Console, 13 F.3d at 667). A new trial will be required if the defendant proves that he or she.
<line: 8> was actually prejudiced by the improper contact. Smith, 455 U.S. at 215, 217-18.

[TEXT]
<line: 10> In short, once credible jury-partiality allegations are made, a hearing is required in order
<line: 11> to determine the effect any improper jury contact had on the defendant's trial. The government
<line: 12> must prove that the contact was harmless in order to avoid a retrial,or, when Smith applies. the
<line: 13> defendant must prove that he was actually prejudiced by the contact in order to get a retrial.

[TEXT]
<line: 15> Here, the Appellate Division ruled that Mr. Rodriguez failed to establish any
<line: 16> unconstitutional influence on juror thirteen. That ruling was not contrary to or an unreasonable.
<line: 17> application of U.S. Supreme Court precedent, for two reasons:

[TEXT]
<line: 19> First, nothing was communicated to juror thirteen about Mr. Rodriguez's case- or so the
<line: 20> trial and appellate courts were entitled to find from the evidence. As the Appellate Division
<line: 21> correctly noted, the culprits, whoever they were, made no express statement or threat. As for any.
<line: 22> implied message, juror thirteen testified to the contrary: he *did not get auy message." he said,.
<line: 23> from the individuals who followed him on the street. (DE 10-2 at 27: emphasis added.) Those
<line: 24> individuals only *kind of laughed and joked as [if] to intimidate" him. (DE 10-2 at 23.) Juror
<line: 25> thirteen "made clear [that] he did not get any message which way the outsiders might have
<line: 26> wanted to influence him, if at all.* (Id.) The motivation, then, could have been purely
<line: 27> mischievous or malicious. (Id. at 24.) About the content of any intended or implicd message. the

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 35

[TEXT]
<line: 2> juror expressly said he knew"nothing at all." (id. at 24) Nor could he say who the individuals
<line: 3>  were in relation to the trial, other than perhaps spectators.16

[TEXT]
<line: 5> So, as the Appellate Division succinctly concluded, *[t]he incident was without content."
<line: 6> (Id.) Mr. Rodriguez has not shown there was contact with juror thirteen about a matter pending
<line: 7> before the jury. It follows that federal precedent does not mandate a presumption of prejudice
<line: 8> with respect to the Impartial Jury Claim. The state courts' rulings were not contrary lo and did
<line: 9> not unreasonably apply United States Supreme Court precedent. At any rate, their fact finding
<line: 10> was reasonable in light of the record before them, consisting of the statements of the jurors
<line: 11> themselves.

[TEXT]
<line: 13> Second, even if there had been an error. my analysis would not be done. As the Supreme
<line: 14> Court has observed, "most" errors, even constitutiona! ones, "can be harmless." Arisona r..
<line: 15> Fulninante, 499 U.S. 279, 306 (1991). Federal courts may not grant habeas relief unless a
<line: 16> petitioner demonstrates that the alleged error had a substantial and injurious effect or influence in
<line: 17> determining the jury's verdict. Brecht v. Abrahamson. 507 U.S. 619, 637 (1993). In the context
<line: 18> of this case, that means that Mr. Rodriguez would have to demonstrate that the allegedly
<line: 19> erroneous retention of juror thirteen "*actually prejudiced" him. (Id. (quoting United States r!
<line: 20> Lae. 474 U.S. 438, 449 (1986).) Based on the record before me, there is no basis for such a
<line: 21> finding.

[TEXT]
<line: 23> The trial court questioned juror thirteen individually. The juror stated that the Incident
<line: 24> would not prevent him from being fair and impartial, or affect his vote in this case. (See DE 10-2

[ABANDON]
<line: 26> 16
<line: 27> Under 28 U.S.C.  2254(d), the state court findings of fact are presumed to bc correct; and Mr.
<line: 28> Rodriguez has failed to rebut that presumption. Further, under 28 U.S.C. $ 2254(d) state court
<line: 29> conclusions of law are binding on a federal court in habeas corpus unless they resulted in a decision that
<line: 30> was "contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as
<line: 31> determined by the Supreme Courl of the United States.

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> 36

[TEXT]
<line: 2> at 23-24.) None of the surrounding circumstances compel a contrary conclusion or cast doubt on
<line: 3> the trial court's fact finding. The individuals who followed juror thirteen made no physical
<line: 4> contact or statement, regarding the trial or anything else. Juror thirteen did not even find the
<line: 5> Incident significant enough to reporl until another juror said she had been approached. (DE 10-2
<line: 6> at 23.) Juror thirteen's conduct thus conveys that his level of fear was mild, corroborating his
<line: 7> statement that he could remain impartial. The trial judge acted within his discretion in
<line: 8> concluding that juror thirteen had not been influenced and that any remaining concerns could be
<line: 9> addressed by some simple additional security measures. Mr. Rodriguez cites nothing beyond
<line: 10> "speculat[ion] that the juror was influenced by fear to find him guilty on all counts.* (DE 10-2 at
<line: 11> 27.) The state courts reasonably found otherwise. Neither untoward influence nor actual
<line: 12> prejudice can be inferred.

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Mr. Rodriguez's $ 2254 Petition expressly concedes that juror thirteen "said he could be
<line: 15> fair.* (DE 1 at 26.) Petitioner does not demonstrate with any evidence that the trial court was nol
<line: 16> entitled to credit that statement, or that the juror in fact deliberated and voted in an unfair or
<line: 17> biased manner. Petitioner thus fails to demonstrate: (1) that the state courts' decisions were
<line: 18> contrary to, or an unreasonable application of, federal precedent; or (2) actual prejudice.

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Ground Three (Impartial Jury Claim) is therefore denied..

[TITLE]
<line: 22> E.
<line: 23> Renewed Motion for Evidentiary Hearing.

[TEXT]
<line: 25> On October 16, 2017, Mr. Rodriguez submitted a renewed motion for an evidentiary
<line: 26> hearing *to be simultaneously reconsidered with his habeas petition ... on his claim that trial
<line: 27> counsel's failure to advise him of his right to testify deprived him of effective assistance of
<line: 28> counsel." (DE 32 at 2.) I will deny that motion. As noted above, the state court held an
<line: 29> evidentiary hearing on that claim and entered factual findings to which I am bound to defer. The

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 37

[TEXT]
<line: 2> Petition being without merit, Mr. Rodriguez's hearing request does not merit further written
<line: 3> discussion and his motion is denied. See generally Zettlemoyer v. Fulcomer, 923 F.2d 284, 298
<line: 4> n.2 (3d Cir. 1991).

[TITLE]
<line: 6> V.
<line: 7> CERTIFICATE OF APPEABILITY

[TEXT]
<line: 9> A certificate of appealability may issue "only if the applicant has made a substantial
<line: 10> showing of the denial of a constitutional right." 28 U.S.C.  2253(c)(2). "A petitioner satisfies
<line: 11> this standard by demonstrating that jurists of reason could disagree with the district court's
<line: 12> resolution of his constitutional claims or that jurists could conclude the issues presented are
<line: 13> adequate to deserve encouragement to proceed further." Miller-El v. Cockrell, 537 U.S. 322, 327
<line: 14> (2003). Applying this standard, the Court rules that a certificate of appealability shall not issue in
<line: 15> this case.

[TITLE]
<line: 17> VI.
<line: 18> CONCLUSION

[TEXT]
<line: 20> For the foregoing reasons, Petitioner's  2254 petition will be denied on the merits. His.
<line: 21> renewed motion for an evidentiary hearing is denied. The Court declines to grant a certificate of
<line: 22> appealability. An appropriate order will be entered.

[ABANDON]
<line: 24> KEVIN MCNULTY
<line: 25> United States District Judge

[TEXT]
<line: 27> DATED: March 21, 2019

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 38
